repnme.cdata!: Jordan - Training and Employment Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
While the assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability is unlikely, and institutional
            development impacts are considered negligible, despite
            satisfactory performances by both the Bank, and borrower.
            The experience of the project, highlights the significant
            effectiveness of linkages between employment and training
            assistance, supported by an organizational structure, in
            achieving workforce development objectives. This also
            facilitates a sustainable employment for the poor, and
            women, adopting as well information dissemination among
            targeted groups, based on an eligibility criteria for
            program participation, on adequate funding support, and
            established contractual obligations between employer and
            employee beneficiaries. However, it should be noted that
            human resources development projects exploring alternate
            delivery mechanisms, would benefit from comprehensive tracer
            studies as a project output, ensuring relevancy of targeted
            resources, addressing the evaluation perceptions, and
            statistically measuring progress. Moreover, the learning
            nature of pilot projects, would greatly benefit from the
            inclusion of forums designed to reinforce, and evaluate
            implementation vis-a-vis the achievement of development
            objectives, and, further exchange recommendations.
            Nonetheless, although the impact assessment study
            demonstrates the potential to leverage the unemployed poor
            into the work force, the project however lost its potential
            to replicate/extend benefits to critical groups, as a result
            of cancellation with no appropriate reference to
            stakeholders. Rather, project design should have guaranteed
            equitable participation, through a policy framework for all stakeholders.

repnme.cdata!: Jordan - Training and Employment Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Training and Employment Support
            Project (TEP) is a pilot project intended to introduce an
            efficient and effective linkage between public expenditures
            for short-term training, and the business community skill
            requirements.  The project components include: (a) a pilot
            training fund to provide funds for in-service training of
            short duration (up to six months) and related support
            services such as occupational needs analysis and employment
            intermediation; (b) monitoring, studies, and evaluation to
            fund survey and studies to evaluate the wage and employment
            impact of the type of training support provided by the
            project in comparison to existing training programs; and (c)
            a project implementation unit to be responsible for overall
            coordination/management of the activities of the project.
